moves.4. Nxd4 Nxd4 5. Qxd4 c5 6. Qa4 a6 7. c4: White has a formidable centre and the doubled c-pawn is not a weakness as it provides open b& d files.
moves.15... d6 16. Rab1: Utilising the open file and preventing Black bishop from developing
moves.16... Rb8 17. Rb6: Blokade b-pawn and pinning d6 pawn
moves.17... Rd8 18. Qd3: White has to protect c-pawn and f-pawn so the rook at f1 can move. Ideal square will be g3 which threatens Blacks king as well
moves.18... Ra8 19. Qg3 a5 20. Rfb1: Again to prevent Black Bishop movement.
moves.20... a4 21. a3: Blacks pawns are blocked and Black  bishop has become a 'bad' one
moves.21... Rb8 22. Ra6: ...axb6(R) will lead to Rxb8(R), entry for the rook to 8th rank
moves.22... Bd7: Black avoids it. But d6-pawn loses support from R at d8
moves.23. e5: take advantage of the pin at d6.
moves.23... Qg6: Grab the d6 pawn after exchange at g6. If ....Qf5 then Bd3
moves.24. Qxg6 hxg6 25. Rxd6 Bc6 26. Rbd1: do not give up control of open file
moves.26... Rde8 27. Kf2: Centralize the king as endgame is approaching
moves.27... Re6 28. Bg4 Rxd6 29. Rxd6: echange is all the better for white
moves.29... f5: Black did not expect en passent
moves.31... Kg7 32. Re6: Laying trap if ...Bd7 then Re7  wins the bishop. If ....Rd8 then Ke3
moves.32... Re8: Black did not fall for the trap. But exchange will favor white as he is two pawns up
moves.33. Rxe8 Bxe8 34. Bf3 b5:
Interesting position!. If 35.Bd5 b4! 36.cxb4 cxb4 37.axb4 Bc6!!
Bxc6 is a taboo. If 38Bxc6 a3! and the Black's a-pawn is unstoppable. White's Bishop can not stop a-pawn due to its own pawn at c4.
If White avoids capture by Be6 Black will play Bd7. Any other move, black will simply push a-pawn
moves.35. cxb5: So White captures the pawn. With 2 pawns up it is a sure win
moves.35... Bxb5 36. Ke3: bringing king to centre for active play
